title: PwC accused of conflict over dual role at Thomas Cook
text:
UK accountants have been banned from providing advice on the remuneration of directors at the companies they audit since 2016.

The head of audit at a rival firm to PwC said: “Regardless of the rules, I’d have felt really uncomfortable offering remuneration advice to an audit client. I’ve never done it and I wouldn’t ever do it.”

They said PwC’s double role represented a “clear conflict” of interest.

“PwC was advising on a remuneration scheme that protected management from exceptional items, while at the same time it was auditing the allocation of exceptional items,” the person said.

A board member at another large accounting firm said: “Providing remuneration advice to audit clients is not allowed now for good reason.”

PwC earned £4m providing “recruitment and remuneration” advice to Thomas Cook between 2007 and 2012, its accounts show.

PwC said it had stopped advising Thomas Cook’s remuneration committee in 2009, and that a £1.7 million fee for remuneration services in 2011 had been for advice on the closure of a defined benefit pension scheme.

“The non-audit work as advisers to the remuneration committee was approved in advance by the audit committee, complied with all relevant regulatory standards and was disclosed in the company’s annual reports,” PwC said.

Advertisement

Thomas Cook’s 2009 annual report said its remuneration committee was “mindful” of PwC’s “dual role” as its adviser and external auditor of the company. “PwC held this dual role because prior to the merger they had acted as remuneration adviser to MyTravel Group and auditor to Thomas Cook,” it stated in the accounts. In 2009, it appointed Kepler Associates as external adviser to the committee.

In 2008 PwC earned £1.3 million providing recruitment and remuneration advice to Thomas Cook, just £300,000 less than it received in fees from auditing the business that year.

Thomas Cook was hit by a shareholder revolt in 2008 over an extra £5 million bonus to then chief executive Manny Fontenla-Novoa on top of £2 million in bonus awards.

More than 60 per cent of independent investors voted against boardroom pay, on which PwC had advised. The 2008 accounts show that EY provided an “independent review” of the benefits policy that led to the supplementary bonus.

A spokesperson for the former directors of Thomas Cook said that “the pre-exceptional profit measure contributed at best 14 per cent of these payments, somewhat exploding the myth that recent management were personally profiting from one-off costs incurred in transforming the business".

One EY insider said the firm had been told to prepare for questions on the accounting treatment of exceptional items.

“Us and PwC reached contrasting conclusions on the accounting treatment of exceptional items,” the person said. “The [business] committee is interested in why that was.”

EY is being investigated by the Financial Reporting Council over its 2018 audit of Thomas Cook. The regulator said it would “keep under close review” the scope of its investigation and the question of whether to open any further probes.

Financial Times
description: The firm has been accused of a conflict of interest for advising senior executives at Thomas Cook on their pay and bonuses while it was the auditor of the now-collapsed travel group.
